I feel your taste all the time we’re apart

Here George compares Clapton’s love of sweets to love of a woman. When he’s not with her, he thinks of her and ‘feels her taste,’ a theme explored in the earlier Beatles song (cover) “A Taste of Honey.”

https://genius.com/The-beatles-a-taste-of-honey-lyrics
You know that what you eat you are

A famous quote, “You are what you eat.”
This means that how overweight you are depends on how much you eat.

This section of the song was partially written by Harrison’s friend, music journalist Derek Taylor.

But you’ll have to have them all pulled out
 After the Savoy truffle

All the sugar Clapton was eating was rotting his teeth. He was going to have to go to the dentist and have all his teeth removed if he wasn’t careful.



“You’ll have to have them all pulled out!” is a widely used old stock expression (at least in the UK and Ireland), used by adults to scare children into slowing down on the sweets.

Creme tangerine and Montelimar
 A ginger sling with a pineapple heart
 Coffee dessert, yes, you know it’s good news

This song was written about Eric Clapton’s love of chocolate.

Savoy Truffle on The White Album was written for Eric. He’s got this real sweet tooth and he’d just had his mouth worked on. His dentist said he was through with candy. So as a tribute I wrote, ‘You’ll have to have them all pulled out after the Savoy Truffle’. The truffle was some kind of sweet, just like all the rest – cream tangerine, ginger sling – just candy, to tease Eric.
- George Harrison, 1977

We all know Ob-La-Di-Bla-Da
 But can you show me, where you are?

George thought that Paul’s song, Ob-La-Di Ob-La-Da, was impersonal- it didn’t say anything about Paul.

This could also reference Paul’s insistence that [the Beatles spend 42 hours recording Ob-la-di Ob-la-da] in a futile attempt to make it into a single.
